post.message:
@author tag is extremely useful when components/classes are reused across different projects and version history is lost (because they are using different repos and sometimes also different VCS). Thats common situation at our projects and @author tag points me usually to right person in case of any questions.

Mostly are @author tags extended and updated during component life time on project. Because it's devs nature to shout: "Hey it was me who fix it!"

There is also another super cool feature of @author tag. It works as "code quality flag" which says ok I know this guy and this code will be pure shit show. Or I know this guy and it will be ok.

Nice post. Love it!

Thanks for your feedback. That is certainly true. The issue is not black and white. As usual in software development, there is no silver bullet which you can apply in each and every situation. You have to weigh tradeoffs of each solution in each case separately depending on your current priorities.
In case version history is unavailable, it is probably best to keep the @author tag. However more that ever, be sure to keep that information up to date. Also, when you are cited as an author, you may arguably feel more responsibility for the piece of code and do your best to maintain its quality. Unfortunately, from my experience it is seldom the case.
So the bottom line might be - if you have your code in the Version Control System at all times, you may want to ommit the @author tag. If not, be aware of the downsides and at least try hard to keep it updated at all times.

The word singleton was indeed popularized as a GoF pattern but that was more than 20 years ago. It's meaning has been generalized since then as "a class that has one (or otherwise predictable number) instance in the system" instead of more specific "class that manages it's own creation in certain way". You may be fighting an irrelevant battle.
Excellent job with the Anki deck, thank you for this. I am just about to get the Spring Enterprise Integration Specialist exam, so maybe I will be able to prepare something similar.
Thanks, I'm glad it was helpful. It would be great if you prepared something similar. If you do, please send me a link.

In my opinion, there are two meanings of singleton. "Singleton", the design pattern as introduced by GOF in the original design patterns book and more general idea of "singleton", that is a class which has only one instance. This post was focused on the first one, the original singleton and the flaw its original implementation has. I don't think there is anything wrong with general idea of singletons as long as the management of having just one instance is clearly separated from the class itself. E.g it is perfectly ok to have spring managed singletons as the instance lifecycle is externally managed by the container and it has none of the flaws of the GOF implementation. Fortunately these days GOF singleton is widely recognised as flawed, but unfortunately is still sometimes being used, especially by those, who just discovered design patterns.

Hi Patrik, Yes I did attend the training. It was the official Spring Web Training by Pivotal, the company behind the Spring Framework. Online version as a videoconference through webex. https://pivotal.io/training.... They have changed the policy and now you can purchase the exam separately for $ 200 - https://pivotal.io/training....

Hey Vojta, thanks for the post. I completely agree with you.

Could you imagine having a Sniff for Code Sniffer that would check these rules?

That would be great way to teach it by context.

Good Idea, it should be pretty straightforward to detect utility classes by static code analysis tools such as SonarQube. You would need to implement a custom rule for that. IT should not be so hard as there is usually a rule for private constructor in utility classes, so you could start from that one (detection of Util Class is already part of that rule).
Is it necessary to attain the training for getting certified for the spring web application exam
It used to be, you had to attend the training to get a certificate voucher. The have recently changed that and from now on you can purchase the certificate separately: https://pivotal.io/training...
Thanks for the Information :)
How can we get the promo code or voucher(as it is compulsory to submit this details for further payment), please guide regarding this.
https://academy.pivotal.io/... Here you can add "Spring Web Application Developer Exam" to you cart and purchase.
If I failed the exam, so within how many days I can again give the exam
The exam can be taken after six weeks, it is right in the first paragraph :)

Even if a Version Control System is used, the code can be distributed without it's history. E.g. as a tarball. Such case is another reason to duplicate the authorship information.

Also AFAIK, here in Czech Republic, if I, as an employee, write a code, the author is actually my employer. Then, depending on the policy, it may happen that the content of the @author tag is different from the name stored in the commit metadata.

I am not saying that we all should use @author tags. But I believe that tracking the information in VCS is not the best idea. Personally, I prefer to maintain two files in the top-level directory. An AUTHORS file and a CONTRIBUTORS file. One for the copyright owners, the other to give credit to the real people who actually wrote the code. I consider this approach to be a decent alternative to the @author and VCS approaches.

It is an viable alternative and it is well suited for high level overview. It does not, however allow such fine grained information as VCS, where you can find a person responsible for each line of code and find a broader context of their change by linking it to particular commit and task. VCS is more suited to find a specific person responsible when working on a larger project with multiple developers, while your approach is more suitable for external users of your code.

Thanks Vojtech Ruzicka for this wonderful article. I will now have an idea of what the actual exam looks like and it will help me a lot to pass the certification. Your resources are very useful and I find it very nice to study.

Well, this is anyway just about storing/retrieving the json, or I can also query the JSONB data? I understand JSONB is not supported in JPA itself, so not sure if JPA based query will work or not.

To be more precious. Imagine I have following code...

Spring Data JPA repository:
@RepositoryRestResource(collectionResourceRel = "business-processes", path = "business-processes")
@Repository
@Api(tags = "business-processes")
public interface BusinessProcessRepository extends
JpaRepository,
QueryByExampleExecutor {

/**
* Method that returns a lista of clients doing a search by the passed name parameter.
* * * @param name * @return list of clients
*/
//Page findAll(Pageable pageable);
List findByName(String name);
}

And following Spring Data Rest controller:
@RequestMapping(
params = {"name"},
method = RequestMethod.GET)
public ResponseEntity<Collection>
findBusinessProcessWithName(
@RequestParam(value = "name") String name) {
return new ResponseEntity(businessProcessRepository.findByName(name), HttpStatus.OK);
}

now imagine my parameter "name" is part of JSONB document, will this approach work?
In general I would like to use JSONB same way as I use @Entities via JPARepository, CrudRepository, etc. I don't see this approach is capable of doing this
good article

To be honest, almost nothing. The book would be much more helpful for me a year ago. However, I did confirm many of my processes and experiences as a good practice. But the chapters are too short to provide any additional information if you are somewhat familar with the topic.

So no mindblowing revelations I am afraid :)

You welcome, I'm glad it was helpful :)

You can undock the whole dev tools into a separate window as usual. However, what you cannot do as far as I know is to separate coverage sub-window into a separate window. Is this what you meant?

Nice post, I used to only use sout as a postfix, didn't come to mind to learn other ones until now. Java is a pretty boilerplate language and this is a very nice feature of the IDE.

Very nice blog post. I am currently searching for such a book myself. I would consider buying it if it were in .mobi format so I could read in in Kindle. Waiting for paperback copy as well as paying for delivery turns me off mostly. As well as I also disagree with the point of making the blog from scratch. If you are already a software developer, you will most probably be bored implementing a blog from scratch- this task is not so complex, it is just a whole lot of work. So why not use an already established free software that you can use and save so much time and more importantly, enthusiasm? Other than that, I would be very interested in reading other chapters. Too bad it is not in electronic format, but I also read Yegor's post about why he doesn't sell in that format and I understand the reasons behind it.
Thanks, glad you like it. Exactly, it is so much useful especially in boilerplate-heavy languages. I especially like those for iteration of collections because you use them so often.

Thank you. Yes, unfortunately it is quite a hassle to obtain the book and then wait that long for the delivery as express shipping is quite steep. Still probably worth reading unless one is experienced blogger.

These problems with utility classes are less problematic in Python/JavaScript /Scala than in Java/C# because you can switch static classes/namespaces easily(math = mymath), and they have support for first-order functions resulting in dramatically less code since you don't have to build complex OOP hierarchies and constructors.

import mymath
math = mymath
def weirdFunc(angle, cos=math.cos, sin=math.sin):
return cos(angle) + sin(angle)

weirdFunc(5.0, cos = customCosMethod)
Thank you for this example, is it definitely true, my post was written from the perspective of Java but it is not so problematic in some other languages.
Thanks for the review; it's quite helpful.
Thank you, I'm glad you find it helpful.

Hi, thank you for your comment. Yes, of course, if your IDE does not have enough memory, it will be slow. Thanks for the link. I'll update the article.

Very nice article.
Thanks.
Thank you, I'm glad you liked it.

What version of javadoc are you using? The information from the @author tag is definitely included in the documentation generated by the version I'm using (1.8.0_152). It's at the bottom of the heading section of class / interface / etc pages, there's an "Author:" section with names listed. Maybe this was added in Java 8 or something?

How has your luck been for TypeDoc and large projects? I've found there's no way to make it output the HTML such that it isn't just a giant top level flat list of things (file or module mode - doesn't matter - only difference seems to be that for module mode it prepends the name of the module with the folder name rather than using the folder name as a navigable feature).

Your example here is with a pretty small project. In larger projects I don't see TypeDoc actually producing output that is more useful than just browsing the code.

Hey,

did you find a way to download only the used lines meanwhile? :)

Greets from Copenhagen,
Hi :) Sorry, I'm afraid not.

Thanks for pointing this out. Authora are not generated by default by javadoc command line tool. You need to explicitly add -author parameter. I should update my article so it is more clear and not misleading.

Hi, to be honest, I didn't try it for large projects, I just did it as a POC for a small one. Then I moved on to Compodoc as it was much better suited for my angular project. Good to know that it does not behave so well for big ones.
Ah ok, my build tool must be setting that automatically then since I didn't have to explicitly set it. Anyway your points are still all valid, just confused me a bit :)
The article is now updated with a link to docs explaining this issue, no more confusion, thanks for pointing it out :)

Hi Vojtech, thanks for article!

For instance, when using headless Chrome or Google Lighthouse
Hi. As far as I know, there is currently no way to retrieve programmatically coverage data through API. Let's hope it will be included in a future release. :)

We have been using swagger at Zonky for a long time and now moving away from it. All those annotations are making controller code way more messy. We introduced spring rest doc which serves also the purpose of testing and we are able to generate stub servers from the documentation test code. Check it out.

Thanks for the tip, I know about it and I am just tinkering with it. :)I like it a lot so far. I just wanted to try both to have a comparison, spring rest docs is going to be my next article :) How do you generate stub server though?
.try looks pretty cool :-), there is still so much to learn about IDEA ...

By

`.andDo(verify().stub("STUB_NAME"))` in the api tests and then packing the results into the wiremock docker image.
